pros: Rewarding work, making a difference, good people, a workplace with a purpose, great benefits, doing good work feels good!  Equity and inclusion is real.
cons: Some leaders who have been here for ages can be pretty harsh but the new leaders are a breath of fresh air.

pros: great people in the MHWC building!
cons: High productivity expectations from higher management, but supervisors are understanding

review_title: Avoid this place at all costs. You have been warned !
job_title: Facilities Coordinator in West Seattle, WA
pros: The only pro I could give this sad pathetic place is that they give you lots of vacation time or as they call personal time off.
cons: The place is run by Multicare who could care less about you as an individual. They do these stupid employee appreciation days here and there and they are so phony about it that it makes you want to puke. Terrible leadership and puppet managers run the place. Staff are the lowest in the barrel because no one wants to work there so they hire the first one to show up for an interview. They place people in upper management that have no skills in their positions. They are out into those positions because they are friends of the CEO or the COO then they hire terrible people to do what should be their job to do. Management style is bullying people around with intimidation style tactics. No matter how good you are or how good you do your job you will never get any credit for it or have any chance of advancement. I was there almost 18 years and basically did the same job the whole time as they bring people in over you because the VP women doesn’t want to be exposed as a complete fraud that she is and was in her position. Avoid this place at all cost.

pros: Company is flexible with personal needs if you’re a person of the executives culture.
cons: I found that the Management team is not of a diverse culture of most. Minority individuals are overlooked unless you’re of the LGBT culture and a family member. Pay is not good with the amount of work. Does a lot of corner cuts to keep grants. Dishonest to county agencies that fund the projects. Very top heavy and don’t find funding for line staff so that the work is done properly. Management lives together and also married to one of the members that is brought in with no experience and blindly placed into an executive role. Also supervised by the spouse. Not a place for a person that wants to service the community.

pros: Very chill place to work,
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement

review_title: Good opportunities for a social worker
pros: Helpful managers, some opportunity for growth, generally dedicated to helping the community.
cons: The pay and staff turnover.

review_title: Not the worst, but definitely not the best.
job_title: Social Service Coordinator in West Seattle, WA
pros: Generous paid time off, some good people on staff, unionized
cons: Little to no support from management, little to no care for patient safety when turning over beds for new patients, disconnect between management and staff

job_title: Child, Youth and Family Therapist in Burien, WA
pros: Great supervisors and managers for the Child, Youth, and Family department Lots of opportunities for collaboration Team-buikding experiences Stipend for trainings/workshops
cons: Cliques in the office High-stress work for low pay (for the area)

pros: Flexible hours, often easy to schedule time off, good healthcare benefits, sense of satisfaction at most locations.
cons:
Navos has had a real issue with staff retention. Often due to not paying certain groups enough for their experience. If a blanket raise is given then all benefits of having worked there for multiple years are erased. Ever since Multicare bought them there have been constant issues with staffing, program development, technology incorporation and many other issues. 

It is certainly not the worst place I have worked but at all the locations it feels as though you are thrown into the deep end and told to sink or swim even though you've never been in a pool before.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Burien, WA
pros: taking care of children with mental health challenges
cons: the children program shout down

pros: vacation time, sick days, health benefits
cons: everything, toxic co-workers, poor management, dangerous work environment

review_title: Money matters more than mental health
pros: Sign on bonus, access to resources
cons: They care more about making money than they do about their employees or client mental health. They will burn you out while asking you to neglect client needs.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Burien, WA
pros:
I like working at Navos for several reasons:

Flexible schedule
Good Pay
The clients - helping and counseling the youth and helping them make safely through another day.
Good health benefits
Training - I like all the training that is offered to all Navos employees (CPS).
cons:
The lack of staff on certain shifts (particular day and swing shifts), it makes is challenging for safety and taking proper breaks.
The lack of accountability that is held to staff members who constantly show up to work late or constantly calls out. There should be a eight minute window for tardiness. Those who come to work late three/ four times or more in one month should get a verbal warning that goes into their file. If tardy five times or more or show the same pattern each month should have one day of work for one day off the schedule.
Being aloud to work minimal overtime
No more ten hour shifts or four day work weeks. Working this job is both physically and mentally draining. And working four days (ten hour shifts) or working three days (twelve hour shifts) allow you to have a third day off. And it really helps us mentally a keeps us from getting burnt out so easily.
To reduce the tardiness and call-outs. There should be a $50 bonus added to MHT's pay check for those who have perfect attendance for each month (something like that).
A lack of annual raises or pay increase. I have been here going on three years and I have only had a .30 cent raise since 2018 (but nurses are being paid ten thousand dollars for recruiting). Are there performance evaluations?
MHT''s aren't included in decision making for clients. Whereas MHT's could be a valuable asset and could add valuable information about clients du to the fact we are on the floor with the client in direct contact. Some of feel unsupported by upper management and excluded (hints all of the exiting of at least five employees in the last two months) . 
The quality of food that the clients are being fed. The youth are eating a lot of peanut butter sandwiches throughout each and week. This is not proper diet. Some of the sandwiches are delivered and the next day the lettuce is dark green, the tomatoes are over ripped and the bread is soggy. The clients were being fed a better quality of food two years ago. 
There is no gym or fitness room for the clients. There needs to be a fitness room with cardio, etc.

pros: I worked in the CLIP program so I was with the older kids. The job could be stressful at times, but you're able to develop good rapport and a good relationship with the youth you work with. My co-workers at the time were also lovely.
cons: Sometimes difficult, emotionally draining. Some weird rules, like no playing music for the kids? Management was open to suggestions though.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Orlando, FL
pros:
Diverse group of kids. 
Great entry level psych job to get experience and your foot in the door. 
Some fun and engaging outings and therapy groups.
Longterm inpatient really lets you form positive(or negative!) rapport with the clients. 
Beautiful campus.
cons:
Disorganized management.
Coworker squabbling common. 
Injuries at work are frequent. Workplace violence is high. 
Secondhand trauma and compassion fatigue lead to quick burnout. 
High turnover rate of staff and mismanaged willynilly callout system, leads to many staff calling out frequently with no disciplinary action and shortstaffed shifts often with no backup support. 
Extremely high stress.

review_title: Enjoyed my time here, but there are still some major issues
job_title: Mental Health Specialist II in Seattle, WA
pros: Effective management and nurses, interesting patients, some solid coworkers, decent/good benefits for full-time, union, schedule is at least consistent for full-time staff, lots of opportunities for OT. Tend to hire in house staff for positions if you become more qualified while working there (i.e. will hire an MHS as a nurse once they get their license).
cons: High acuity with sometimes poor staffing, you get guilt-tripped if you call off for being sick.  Potential for drama with coworkers.  Pay should be higher for the amount of danger you're putting yourself in and the stress/trauma that you're bound to encounter.  Very little engagement from higher-ups in the company (those above the nurse managers, CEO seems not to value or care about the inpatient hospital. Depending on what floor you're on/ which shift you work, you may not get any interaction with other members of the patients' care team, such as their doctors or social workers and this can cause a significant disconnect between different staff. MHS's input is often undervalued.

job_title: Case Aide in West Seattle, WA
pros: Four ten schedules, decent benefits package
cons: Extremely negative environment, clients get little assistance and staff does not care.

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in West Seattle, WA
pros: Good people and flexible schedule,
cons: We are always understaff, low morale

review_title: More focused on revenue than clients/staff
job_title: Mental Health Technician in Seattle, WA
pros: Nice co workers, opportunities to learn
cons: Upper management doesn’t care about their own employees mental health

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator (HUC) in Seattle, WA
pros: The Pay is decent to me.
cons: Better Management can be reviewed.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Burien, WA
pros: clinicians tend to support one another
cons: heavy work load, low pay

pros: Good co-workers and teamwork, good learning opportunities
cons: Leadership team is out of touch

job_title: Mental Health Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: It is clear that all the staff are there because they either have experience with mental illness themselves or with someone close to them, Or just because they are caring individuals and want to learn. Everyone is creative and determined to make sure the patients have everything they need within the confines of what they can have. And finally, it doesn't matter if you're just co-workers or buddies, it really feels like everyone has your back when incidents occur.
cons:
The atmosphere is still very institutional, but the higher ups in the company said a new building is scheduled, and if you look at the Burien location, something like that would be amazing, and may be in the works. 
It can be a little confusing to learn exactly how the hierarchy goes, but that also is a plus as you're given a lot of free reign and independent authority, don't abuse it!

job_title: Mental Health Specialist in West Seattle, WA
pros: This role is helpful to the community. It also allows you to add this work to your resume. That is a big bonus for the Seattle area.
cons: The units are often highly acute and poorly managed. Staff is exposed regularly to unsafe conditions with no immediate remedy in sight. Management generally doesn't care and often acts as a filter for complaints with no intention on making the enviroment better. Management will never come in, even when the unit is short staffed. Navos hospital as a facility isn't equipped to handle some of the clients that it does but take regularly take on clients that put staff in very vulnerable positions.

job_title: Mental Health Specialist in West Seattle, WA
pros: There are a ton of opportunities for overtime. Good benefits
cons: Given that there are a ton of opportunities for overtime, the units are extremely short staffed. The units are way to acute for the staff we have and extremely poorly managed. Coworkers are burnt out and start drama from everything. The job is way too dangerous. You could make more money working elsewhere and not be assaulted by patients.

pros: Benefits, no long distance traffic, parking
cons: Upper management and supervisors don't communicate.  Hot mess.

pros: Excellent coworkers and a really nice team environment. The work is hard, because of the nature of the CLIP program, but it was rewarding. I think back on my time there fondly. The kids made it worth it! Not for the faint of heart, but truly a rewarding position. Leaving for law school was an incredibly difficult thing to deal with because of the close bond formed with coworkers and kids.
cons: Funding funding funding funding funding

review_title: supervisor has done several things that would have gotten him fired somewhere else but they won't do anything about it
job_title: Geriatric Mental Health Worker in Seattle, WA
pros: My coworkers have been great; the psychiatrists are truly amazing. A lot of people who have stuck around do so because they really care about the work they do and are willing to be abused by their employers to continue the work.
cons: Having such poor supervision has taken a team with great potential and significantly held back our abilities. The boss uses intimidation and threats of firing to keep you in your place. Everyone I know on the team hates their job.

pros: Your ideas and insights are welcomed in the Adjunctive Therapies department. You are allowed to work within your own theoretical lens and conduct therapy groups- no case management.
cons: The rest of the hospital does not always understand the therapist roll- so you often have to educate and create boundaries to keep the therapy space sacred for the patients.

job_title: Geriatric Mental Health Counselor in West Seattle, WA
pros: The CEO (David Johnson) is dynamic, energetic, and very personable; the company is growing, becoming a leader in the mental health community in Seattle with the additions of the programs at Ruth Dykeman Children's Services and others.
cons: The lack of adequate communication between the various programs; low attendance at all staff meetings.

pros: They have plenty training access for employees( both online and workshop), and advance resources due to such a big agency.
cons: Corrupt management, unprofessional managers without licenses, profession ethics ( unbounded with any licensing board). Most managers are with this agency for over 20 years, know everybody, goes no where.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in West Seattle, WA
pros: The team I work with (child, youth, and family) is supportive and energetic. I think many people at Navos stay for their colleagues. People (including myself) also stay for our clients and wanting to help support vulnerable people.
cons: It's community mental health. The pay is low (though every clinical staff recently got a bump), the training is minimal, and the work is challenging.

review_title: The mission statement is nice to read but there’s nothing behind it.
pros: Flexible schedule, ability to work within your own theoretical framework, and many training opportunities.
cons: Flat out dishonesty, discrimination, racism, lack of job security, benefits suck, and lots of pressure to perform and produce outcomes. Not to mention, upper management is functioning on outdated notions and is completely unwilling to change or progress.

pros: Difficult to think of positives
cons: They tend to hire people who are trying to get their license. Most are unlicensed and unmotivated if they are. I see lazy and manipulative workers. This is a scary place to work if you value your license and your patients. burn out and poor management.

review_title: I loved the creativity I was allowed to use in my position, but I had to work hard to stay out of politics.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Seattle, WA
pros: Client-centered, lots of good people
cons: political in some areas, keeping some employees in upper management who did not serve the company's best interest

pros: Steady work for a company that really cares about patient safety and care quality
cons: limited resources at times for salaries and patient care

pros: If you want to be part of an organization making difference in the lives of vulnerable people, I recommend Navos as a rewarding place to work.
cons: Some employees have been at this organization too long and some are in jobs that are over their heads. Continue to make diversity a priority!

pros: good benefits, flexible scheduling, team atmosphere, applicable experience in the field of mental health, rewarding job, decent pay. opportunity to help disadvantaged youth
cons: inconvenient hours, not much opportunity for advancement, stressful work environment, physically and emotionally demanding, lots of staff turnover, not much consistency/continuity

pros: Most 5 and 4 star reviews are written by Navos. The red flag is how they full language from their mission statement and put it directly into the review,  see: equity, inclusion,  etc
cons: Completely top down working environment. HR is yielded like a hammer to remove employees via false claims. These claims are never researched.

pros:

Pay is better then most places

pros: Mission driven, culture of patient first, profit second
cons: Clunky systems, senior leadership turnover

pros: Always trying to improve working environment and dedication to providing Trauma Informed Care

pros: Stable work, opportunity for overtime
